title: 107_s1656
content: The Act may be cited as the "Veterans Benefits Administration Improvement Act of 2001". The Veterans Benefits Administration is responsible for processing veterans' compensation and pension claims accurately and timely. Concerns have been raised about the accuracy of claims processing, with new measurements showing lower accuracy rates than previously reported. Adequate training for claims adjudicators is crucial as the Administration faces potential workforce reductions. The Veterans Benefits Administration needs to ensure efficient processing of veterans' claims as 30% of its workforce is set to retire by 2003. Adequate training for claims adjudicators is crucial to avoid delays in providing compensation and pension benefits. The backlog of pending work in September 2001 was 533,029 claims, with an expected appeals processing time of 621 days. SEC. 3. IMPROVEMENT OF PROCESSING OF VETERANS BENEFITS CLAIMS. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a plan for improving claims processing within 90 days of this Act. The plan includes mechanisms for better training of adjudicators, enhancing employee accountability, and improving data collection to reduce errors in claims adjudications. The Veterans Benefits Administration aims to identify recurring errors in claims adjudications by improving data collection related to common human body impairments and deficiencies in medical evidence. Mechanisms will be implemented to review claims processing accuracy, evaluate the impact of training systems, and set quantifiable goals. Consultation with veterans organizations and other interested parties is required in developing the plan. The Secretary shall consult with veterans organizations and other parties in developing the plan under subsection (a). The plan shall be implemented 60 days after submission and can be modified with proper notification. Reports on plan implementation are to be submitted every six months. The Secretary will submit a report every six months to assess the implementation of the plan, including whether the goals are being achieved. Funding for the plan will come from appropriations for the Veterans Benefits Administration.
